column1: Thangorodrim (pron. ) was a group of three volcanic mountains in the Iron Mountains in the north of Middle-earth during the First Age. The highest peaks in Middle-earth

Thangorodrim was said to have been the piles of slag from Morgoths furnaces and rubble from the delving of Angband
column2: but at the same time they were solid enough to form sheer precipices; Maedhros was nailed to a cliff of Thangorodrim
column3: and Húrin imprisoned on a high terrace. The tops of Thangorodrim perpetually smoked
column4: and sometimes spewed forth lava. The three peaks of Thangorodrim functioned as furnaces for Morgoths great smithies deep in Angband.

column1: For a time the Eagles lived on Thangorodrim
column2: but at some time during the First Age they removed to the Crissaegrim near Gondolin.

column1: At the base of the south face of the middle peak was the Great Gates of Angband
column2: a deep canyon leading into the mountain
column3: lined with towers and forts. There were also a number of secret gates scattered around the sides of the mountain group
column4: from which Morgoths hosts could issue forth and surprise their foes.

column1: Along with Beleriand and the entire west of Middle-earth
column2: Thangorodrim was destroyed in the War of Wrath at the end of the First Age when the defeated dragon Ancalagon the Black fell on them.
